body:
Yeah, right now it only releases tags...

I don't know what is best here... maybe this is a v2 thing...

@caarlos0 I think releasing tags is definitely the most useful thing and I don't think we even need to support other use cases.

However, currently you can only correctly release a tag when you switch to the tagged branch before running GoReleaser.
If I'm on my `master` branch, for example, and I have one commit more there than my latest tag, The binary will be built including this one new commit. 
It should use the source of the tag instead of the current branch.

Hmmm, that makes a lot of sense... If not that, at least exiting 1 to let the user know...

`git checkout` the tag may not be so simple, since there can be unchanged files, etc...

issue.title: Automatic tagging

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issue.body:
At least two people I talked to mentioned that they wish `goreleaser` would automatically create a tag for them.

I guess there are quiet a few people out there not running GoReleaser on CI.
When running it manually, it would be definitely nice if running `goreleaser` would take a version number or something and create the tag for you.
I wish we can support this use case too.

Maybe we can add a command-line argument like `-tag string`.
When you set it the specified tag will be created for you.

For the "create a new tag" scenario we would also not run into the problem we had with #72 
because we don't need to switch branches since the current state is exactly what will end up in the tagged version.
Creation of a new tag should be only allowed with a clean Git state though.


In addition these checks the [np](https://github.com/sindresorhus/np) tool (for node.js) does could also ne useful for us:
> - Ensures you are publishing from the `master` branch
> - Ensures the working directory is clean and that there are no unpulled changes
> - Reinstalls dependencies to ensure your project works with the latest dependency tree
> - Runs the tests
